Problem: the .22 mag fired from a pistol is way under performing due to the fact that factory magnum ammunition is optimized to be fired from rifles, meaning the pressure curve of the powder is maintained longer to use the length of the barrel. Where as when this ammo is fired from a short barrel a large portion of the powder is just blown out the barrel and not used to produce velocity.

Glass is dense.  The FMG is deflecting and the glass is also diffusing some of the energy by swinging backwards.  The unjacketed lead is wrapping around the glass and applying pressure and resonances to it.  If you start shooting with anything with more punch, you're going to want to shoot with better protection.  In the set-up, that glass could come flying back around and hit you.  You definitely don't want to get hit with that or a shard of that.  You're also dealing with a curved surface on a dense, irregular object.  The change for ricochets of high power rounds goes up dramatically.

Regarding the complaints by viewers about the bullet not holding its shape in your last video. Isn't that how they are designed to act once the round strikes its target? From what I understand, rounds are designed to "mushroom" immediately after impact. This is so maximum damage is inflicted. To put this into context, let's think about hunters and those using weapons for self defense such as police officers or even the person who would like to protect their person, property, and/or home(and possibly their family in it if they have a family). All of these individuals would prefer a round designed so that it "mushrooms" as much as possible so that it inflicts the most damage possible. For hunting, harvesting an animal should be done in the most humane way possible. So, the shot should first be at vital points but at that it should still only take one shot so that the animal suffers the least. To maximize this chance for a "one shot one kill" a round with the maximum stopping power or "mushroom" effect is crucial. Someone using a weapon in self defense of themselves, others, and property must neutralize the threat as quickly as possible. If one uses a bonded jacketed hollow point, such as the 9mm Winchester PDX1 Defender, then the threat is more efficiently neutralized. As for what this man used in the video, if the rounds shown at 0:28 are the same .22 rounds used in the .22 video last made then it is a soft tipped hollow point round. Therefore, it was meant to mushroom and break apart as it made contact.

As a disclaimer before someone proceeds to retort my use of the 9mm as an example I am fully aware that there are rounds out there with greater stopping power. The .45ACP is one I can come up with right away but there are others I know of as well. Soft tipped rounds are also ones that mushroom once striking a surface. I also know there are rounds that are meant to hold their shape and penetrate the target.

"Prince Rupert's Drops ... are toughened glass beads created by dripping molten glass into cold water, which causes it to solidify into a tadpole-shaped droplet with a long, thin tail.
These droplets are characterized internally by very high residual stresses, which give rise to counter-intuitive properties, such as the ability to withstand a blow from a hammer or a bullet on the bulbous end without breaking, while exhibiting explosive disintegration if the tail end is even slightly damaged. " - Wikipedia

Awesome how tough that thing is. The "FMJ" .22LR is really nothing more than a thin plating, it doesn't amount to much, it helps keep the barrel from lead fouling is all. But even the ceterfire FMJ rounds splatter when they hit steel. Looks like that glass is as strong as steel, but it goes against my logic. Safety glass is intentionally made with internal stresses like this so that when they break they disintegrate into a million "popcorn" pieces. But they aren't very strong. In fact heat treated safety glass seems to be very flexible. We replaced a plate glass sliding glass door with safety glass and that thing looked like wobbly rubber when we closed it compared to the stiffer plate glass, same thickness. Glass is pretty strange stuff.

Hey Destin! I think you've got it wrong with FMJ. I've got a pretty good theory about why the FMJ bullets seem to do less damage to the drops than pure lead. The lead bullets being much softer actually deliver more energy to the drop than FMJ(in this case this is vibrational/kinetic energy). This can be compared to a simple Charpy Impact Test performed on steel, where energy absorbed by the specimen is inversely proportional to the temperature of the test(and directly proportional to the plasticity).

Guns are fun, but you should try and hit the drop with some sort of diamond hammer to properly test it's hardness. (or shoot it with a diamond bullet).

Cheers!

Have you considered trying annealing a Prince Ruberts Drop (PRD) to see if the bullet would shatter the unstressed drop?

I would theorize that any led bullet will loose to the PRD, but steel buckshot may have a chance. The only way to break the head of the drop is for the pressure applied by the impact to exceed the compressive stress in the glass surface. As the bullets get bigger, the force is also getting spread out over the surface and the net result is still a very low pressure on the PRD surface. Even with a smaller bullet, the contact stress is limited by yield strength of the material, so it will never get higher than the ultimate strength of led, which is fairly low.

It's like bolt preload: you torque down a bolt on a fitting and the bolt only sees the preload stress, regardless of the tension applied to separate the fittings, as long as the tension does not exceed the preload. The compression in the glass surface must be exceeded for the glass to break. That requires a large P/A.. so either increase the P or decrease the A. Also, since you are hanging the PRDs from string, the pressure is further limited by inertia transfer during the impulse. The impulse is long with the lead bullets since the entire bullet deforms and melts around the glass, so most of the energy of the bullet is actually accelerating the PRD into kinetic energy.

I submit that the copper jacket has little effect on the overall material yield strength of the bullet, and the only way you'll have a chance to crack a PRD with a bullet is by using a steel core/steel shot. I would not be surprised if a PRD did survive a .50 BMG, as long as the tail stays intact. In which case, good luck finding the PRD down range!

It was probably the velocity. If I remember right the 22 LR was out of a rifle which may account for the difference, if the air bubble wasn't the factor. Larger bullet or even KE isn't generally the winning factor when talking penetration. A larger factor is velocity. For example a 55 gr 5.56 XM193 which travels around 3100 fps (16 inch barrel) can penetrate level 3 body armor, but a 62 gr 5.56 M855 which travels around 2700 fps (again 16 inch barrel) won't penetrate level 3 body armor even with it's steel "perpetrator". 38 special out of  a revolver doesn't have very much velocity in comparison to a 22 LR, so I would actually expect a 22 LR to penetrate better.
